description: How has our image of Italy arrived to us? Where does the story begin and who has recounted, rewritten, and rearranged it over the centuries? In this course, we will study Italy's rich and complex past and present. We will carefully read literary and historical texts and thoughtfully watch films in order to attain an understanding of Italy that is as varied and multifacted as the country itself. Group work, discussions and readings will allow us to examine the problems and trends in the political, cultural and social history from ancient Rome to today. We will focus on: the Roman Empire, Middle Ages, Renaissance, Unification, Turn of the Century, Fascist era, World War II, post-war and contemporary Italy.
name: ITALIAN HIST ON SCREEN: How Movies Tell the Story of Italy (in English)

section.name: ITALIAN HIST ON SCREEN: How Movies Tell the Story of Italy (in English)

values.comments:
This course is designed to explore Italian history and current politics, culture, and society. It will cover material from ancient Rome to present day with specific emphasis on the Roman Empire, Middle Ages, Renaissance, Unification, Turn of the Century, Fascist Era, World War II, post-war Italy, and contemporary Italy. It will also investigate the source of Italian historical documentation and its perception. The course will be in English. Material will be presented through media such as films, in-class discussions, journal entries, and readings. 

Many students were pleased with this course. They described it as “interesting,” “informative, comprehensive” and “a lot of fun.” Some expressed mixed feelings about the emphasis based on film in the course, while others found the class discussion to have little merit. 

Similarly, the reaction to Veneziano-Broccia was entirely positive; one student commented that she was “a fabulous teacher and [made] all the hard work for the class worthwhile.” Others said she was “fantastic” and “excellent” and even said she was the “nicest, most pleasant woman alive” and another said that she was “the most wonderful professor… ever.” 

This course does cover a significant amount of history and many students commented that the structure of the class makes it very “straight forward.” Other students commented that the grading system seemed “more opinion… [than] topic based.” Students expressed mixed feelings about the course structure. Some found that the regular, weekly assignments could become “overwhelming” -- one student described the assignments as “incredibly excessive [with] 60-90 descriptive questions [for] one reading [along with] movies to watch, and other readings” -- although other students believed the work to be very manageable. This course does require film screenings, which can be completed outside of class or during class meetings. Participation in class discussion is required and journal entries and timelines are other forms of regular assignments. This course has no pre-requisites and student feedback indicated that this course successfully covers and taught students a comprehensive outlook on Italian history, “much more than [they] ever expected [to learn].”
